text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with mumbo sauce that's right i'm
going to show you what a washington dc's
most iconic culinary creations i mean
this is right up there with the city's
famous hmm what do they make in
washington i can't think of anything off
the top of my head so I guess Washington
would be considered more of a drinking
town or at the very least a town that
makes you want to drink but regardless
this delicious sweet and sour condiment
is very popular there where it's served
in Chinese takeout places on chicken
wings and for some reason french fries
so if you're still watching let's go
ahead and get started and we'll begin by
adding 1 can of tomato paste into this
saucepan and the big debate among mumbo
sauce aficionados is whether the base
should be tomato paste or ketchup and
every time I hear about an argument like
that I always think to myself why can't
we use both so that's what I'm going to
do for my version I'm also gonna add in
some ketchup to the paste and then once
that's in we will continue on please in
like a Polynesian with a big old splash
of pineapple juice and more than a
splash will do like a cup and then to
that we will add a cup of white
distilled vinegar which is the vinegar
we use when we want to add a siddha tea
but not add any extra flavors like with
a wine vinegar for example I'm also
gonna toss in the juice of one freshly
squeezed lemon as well as a pinch of
white sugar to help balance out all
those acidic ingredients we already
added plus we will also add some honey
and if he can you always want to try to
use local honey although I forget why
but anyway we'll continue on with a
little bit of salty umami flavor in the
form of soy sauce and no not the
low-sodium kind that sort of defeats the
purpose and then next up if we want a
little bit of heat which we do we'll
toss in a spoon of cayenne and then last
but not least we will finish up with a
rounded tablespoon a freshly grated
ginger and that is gonna be it for our
mumbo sauce ingredients and then we'll
take a whisk and give this a thorough
mixing and by the way you certainly
don't have to make this much I'm doing
sort of an extra-large version which of
course I'm gonna call a mambo Grande I
wish I could have come up with a better
name but anyway we'll stir that together
and then head over to the stove where
we're gonna put this on medium-high heat
where we will turn it into a sauce by
simply letting it simmer for 10 minutes
so what we'll do is simply let this come
up to temperature maybe give it a stir
or two and as soon as our mixture starts
to bubble we will back our heat down to
medium-low and let it simmer fairly
gently for 10 minutes okay so we're not
really cooking or reducing the sauce but
we do want to give it enough time for
those flavors to meld together and if
everything's gone according to plan
after 10 minutes it should look
something similar to this and then all
we'll do at this point is turn off the
heat and then give it a stir and then I
like to let it sit for a little while to
cool down just a bit before I strain it
and yes you could strain this right away
while dangerously hot but if you do
somehow some way a little bit will
splash on you and I'm not sure why
you'll have to take that up with the
universe but I do recommend letting it
sit for a little bit before we strain it
and by the way speaking of optional
steps you don't have to strain this you
can certainly use it as is but since I
added that fresh ginger which could be a
little bit fibrous I do like to strain
that out so I have a perfectly smooth
sauce but of course that's going to be
up to you you guys are after all the
party bosses of your Mambo sauces and
you wield all the decision-making power
in your kitchen but for me personally it
is worth the extra minute and then one
strain if we are doing that our Mambo
sauce is now ready to use and right here
you get a look at that just thick enough
texture an absolutely gorgeous color I
mean that almost looks good enough to be
artificial so I was really thrilled with
how this came out and although I've
never had an actual real Mambo sauce
from DC I assume this was spot-on and
just as good if not better than anything
you're gonna get there so with that let
me go ahead and serve some up on some
experimental rice coated chicken wings
which explains their possibly odd look
and while I'm not sure about french
fries this really was an amazing
combination right this is sort of like a
sweet and sour sauce meets a plum sauce
meets a barbecue sauce meets that
mystery clear orange sauce you get in
that package when you buy frozen egg
rolls so kind of different and familiar
exotic yet comforting
alright fairly sweet but also very tangy
with lots of tropical fruit eNOS and
just a little bit of heat at the end so
I very much enjoyed dipping those in and
then decided to serve some more with a
more traditional pouring the sauce over
the top which really does make for a
striking borderline scary presentation
and while they were Messier I do think I
preferred this method it just seemed
more mumbo ish oh and by the way quick
production note I actually had a wisdom
tooth pulled yesterday and I have
stitches in my mouth so my apologies if
I slurred a few words and this sounded
more like a mumble sauce but as they say
the show must go on and as I said I
really did like how these came out but
anyway that's it my West Coast take on
mumbo sauce since we're heading straight
to the middle of chicken wing season a
bowl or two of this sauce may come in
handy
which reminds me stay tuned for the rice
krispies chicken wing experiment which
will be coming soon but in the meantime
I really do hope you give this
interesting and very unique Washington
DC condiment a try soon so head over to
food which is calm for all the
ingredient amounts of more info as usual
and as always enjoy
[Music]
you
